claim: Americans earn less  than people in certain countries.

supporting.text: According to World Bank data, the median household income in the United States is higher than in most countries, including many developed nations.

attacks.text: According to World Bank data, the median household income in the United States is higher than in most countries, including many developed nations.
The median income does not account for cost of living differences, which are significantly higher in the U.S. compared to many other developed nations.
Even after adjusting for purchasing power parity (PPP), U.S. median household income remains higher than in most countries.
The World Bank data may not fully capture income inequality, which is higher in the U.S. than in many other developed nations, skewing the median.
While inequality is higher, the median is still a robust measure as it is less affected by extreme values than the mean.

supporting.text: Countries like Switzerland, Luxembourg, and Norway have higher average wages than the United States, as reported by OECD statistics.

attacks.text: Countries like Switzerland, Luxembourg, and Norway have higher average wages than the United States, as reported by OECD statistics.
OECD statistics may not account for differences in cost of living, which is significantly higher in Switzerland, Luxembourg, and Norway compared to the U.S.
Even after adjusting for purchasing power parity (PPP), these countries still maintain higher disposable incomes than the U.S. in many cases.
The OECD data may not reflect median wages, which could show a different picture due to income inequality in the U.S. compared to these nations.
Median wage comparisons still favor countries like Switzerland and Norway over the U.S., as their income distributions are more equitable.

supporting.text: The U.S. has a higher GDP per capita than many countries, but income inequality means some Americans earn significantly less than the national average.

attacks.text: The U.S. has a higher GDP per capita than many countries, but income inequality means some Americans earn significantly less than the national average.
GDP per capita is not a direct measure of individual earnings, and many countries with lower GDP per capita have higher median incomes due to better wealth distribution.
Median income comparisons show that Americans still earn more than the majority of countries, even accounting for inequality.
Income inequality in the U.S. is so severe that a significant portion of the population earns less than people in countries with lower GDP per capita but more equitable distribution.
Studies show that even lower-income Americans have higher purchasing power than comparable income groups in many other countries due to lower costs in certain sectors.

supporting.text: Certain high-income professions in the U.S., such as tech and finance, often earn more than comparable roles in other countries.

attacks.text: Certain high-income professions in the U.S., such as tech and finance, often earn more than comparable roles in other countries.
The claim refers to average earnings, not just high-income professions, and the U.S. median income is lower than some countries like Switzerland and Norway.
Even within high-income professions, U.S. salaries are often offset by higher costs of living, healthcare, and education, reducing net disposable income.
The U.S. has significant income inequality, so while some professions earn more, many others earn far less than their counterparts in other developed nations.

supporting.text: Minimum wage workers in the U.S. earn less than their counterparts in some European countries with higher mandated minimum wages.

attacks.text: Minimum wage workers in the U.S. earn less than their counterparts in some European countries with higher mandated minimum wages.
The cost of living in the U.S. is generally lower than in many European countries, which offsets the lower minimum wage.
Even with lower cost of living, the purchasing power of U.S. minimum wage workers is still lower than in some European countries with higher wages.
Many U.S. states and cities have minimum wages higher than the federal minimum, narrowing the gap with European counterparts.
Even with higher local minimum wages, the overall average minimum wage in the U.S. remains lower than in many European countries.
The U.S. has a more flexible labor market, allowing for greater upward mobility and higher earnings potential beyond minimum wage.
Upward mobility does not change the fact that current minimum wage workers earn less than their European counterparts.

supporting.text: Purchasing power parity (PPP) adjustments show that while nominal incomes may be lower in some countries, cost of living differences can affect real earnings.

attacks.text: Purchasing power parity (PPP) adjustments show that while nominal incomes may be lower in some countries, cost of living differences can affect real earnings.
PPP adjustments do not account for non-monetary quality-of-life factors such as healthcare, education, and infrastructure, which can significantly differ between countries.
Even with PPP adjustments, certain high-income countries still show substantially higher real earnings compared to the U.S., indicating a genuine income gap.
PPP data can be unreliable due to varying methodologies and incomplete cost-of-living data across different regions within countries.
International organizations like the World Bank and IMF standardize PPP calculations to ensure comparability and reliability across countries.
